newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity ends mostly up in seesaw session.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity ends mostly up in seesaw session.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures settled mostly higher Friday in a seesaw session which the complex struggled for direction amid falling western physical prices and concerns over status of the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station (SONGS).
The 1,080 megawatt (MW) SONGS unit 3 remained off line with a restart expected Sunday night while engineers corrected a water contamination problem in the unit's lube oil system, the operator said.
The unit, in San Clemente, Calif., was earlier scheduled to return to service yesterday.
The adjacent 1,070 MW unit 2 was holding at 70 percent power while maintenance work on a main feedwater pump was being carried out.
There was growing belief that SONGS unit 3 may ultimately need to be shut to complete the pump repairs, traders said.
August Palo Verde (PV) futures settled up 14 cents at $36.82 a MWh after hitting resistance at $37.10 just 20 cents off its life-of-contract high.
September PV finished down nine cents at $29.11. Most deferred months were inactive.
August California-Oregon Border (COB) settled down 14 cents at $21.90 after bouncing between $21.80 and $22.15.
September COB finished up six cents at $22.19. Other COB contracts ended five to 20 cents higher.
Firm, peak electricity prices for Saturday/Monday at PV slipped $10.00 to $39.00-44.00 a MWh, while those at COB lost a dollar to $16.25-17.25 ahead of lower weekend demand.
Market sources said they were unsure about the direction of complex due to ongoing uncertainty at SONGS.
"It's really hard to tell with the San Onofre situation," a West Coast power trader said.
In generation news, output at the 1,158 MW WNP-2 nuclear power plant in Richland, Washington, rose to 92 percent of capacity as of early Friday.
The 750 MW Mohave coal-fired unit 3, which was shut Monday for repairs, was expected to resume operations Saturday.
The 254 MW Valmy coal-fired unit 1 in Nevada was unlikely to return to full power until the weekend, after its output was halved Tuesday because of a tube leak.
There was talk of a 700 MW unit at the Colstrip coal-fired power plant in Montana going off line over the weekend for unplanned repairs, but this could not be confirmed.
A 446 MW unit at the Huntington coal-fired plant in Utah was also said to be shut for short-term repair work.
Separately, southbound capacity on the AC segment of the Pacific Intertie transmission system was set for a250 MW cut to 3,200 MW today between 0900 and 1600 PDT for maintenance.
Temperatures in the Southwest were expected to average near seasonal levels next week, while those in Northwest would run normal to above normal.
((--R Leong, New York Power Desk +1 212 859 1627))
